text: Today I'm going to be showing you how to quantize audio in Ableton.
So this can be really useful if you're recording a lot of vocals or guitars, specifically more
things like guitars and instruments that you will want to quantize to make more musically
pleasant and more on the grid.
Now you never want to overdo this because you still want there to be like a human feel,
but you can definitely quantize things really quick and easily with audio, something that
I didn't find out Ableton could do for a while.
So I have this loop here with just a simple guitar, drums and some pads.
Let's go ahead and take a listen and notice how the guitar, this recorded guitar is out
of time.
The whole performance or certain parts seem to happen a little too soon.
So really quick and easy in Ableton.
All you got to do is, is you want to turn on your work modes.
Now complex and complex pro are going to be the two, your two biggest modes to use
here mainly because they're just the most accurate representation of the warping.
So like I would usually keep it on complex or complex pro.
I'm going to go ahead and leave it on complex pro.
Now the first thing you want to do after you've engaged warping is kind of look at your grid
and try to make your grid size the smallest it could possibly be for this performance.
So looking at this performance is pretty simple, right?
I just have chords hitting on like the beginning of each measure.
And then there's a couple of other like notes happening on off beats in the measure.
So what I'm going to do is I'm going to change the grid size here down to something that
makes more sense for quantizing because what we're going to be doing here is we're going
to be essentially quantizing every single warp marker that Ableton creates automatically
for these transients.
So basically all you have to do is once you get the grid size to a more reasonable sizing
here because you know these are going to snap, right?
They're going to snap either left or right so you wouldn't want this to be you know like
this because then this is only going to snap like to right there.
You want it to be able to snap to where it should be musically.
So this can kind of take a little bit of getting used to but basically like I can tell that
if I have it as this grid size all of these markers are going to be automatically snapping
to the right location.
So all you want to do is click to make sure you're engaged in the audio, press command
A to select everything and then the same as quantizing just press command U. And what
that's going to do is that's going to automatically engage all of those work markers and start
to quantize them.
Now I have my quantize settings at only 52 percent.
You can access that by holding shift command U. But if I put this at 100 percent just so
we can see this really in action.
So now you can see that all of those guitar hits that were happening a little too soon
are now just automatically shifted to be exactly where they should be.
And you can see that sometimes it's not perfect right like I can tell over here that this
is probably wrong.
So let's go ahead and listen to it.
So these two just because of where the original markers were like if I come on undo this command
Z you can see that because this was so off originally right that this actually snapped
to this grid grid line instead of this one.
So again that's why you know maybe even making this grid size slightly smaller will make
sure that they snap automatically to the right spot since I know this is all basically just
quarter notes or whole notes are in each one of each measure.
I can make the grid really big like this and it should be fixed that issue for us.
So if I go ahead and command U and that already went ahead and fixed those last ones over
here.
And then this last little hit here it looks like it's also coming in a bit early.
Now what I would do is that because I don't need any of that.
I think this work marker is is on the right spot but the actual transient that it picked
up was the wrong one.
I wanted it to move this work this tone.
So I'm going to do is just hold shift and drag this to bring that transient in line
with this work marker.
So now at the end here and just like that you know quantized and perfectly in time right
did not take a lot of effort.
It really is about finding that grid size the shortcuts for that by the way command
to to make your grid size bigger command one to make it smaller and then you can do command
three to put turn on triplets and then command four turns on and off the grid.
But I usually just kind of use come I don't write a lot of triplets so command one and
command to find that largest grid size that's possible for your performance.
And then that way you don't have to do as much work right.
I didn't have to go in there and manually move a bunch of transients other than this
one over here because of selecting that grid size but it's really that easy.
I mean obviously this can get more time consuming if you've got a bigger performance but for
the most part you know this is great for quickly getting your stuff in time.
